Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives
Rabbi Arthur Schneier Papers
Schneier, Arthur, Rabbi
TAM.694
96.5 Linear Feet in 6 record cartons, 188 manuscript boxes, 12 half manuscript boxes, 6 small flat boxes, 3 oversize flat boxes, and 5 media boxes.
39 audiocassettes
7 film reels
6 videocassettes (vhs)
119.40 Gigabytes in 15,417 computer files.
1956-2016 1946-2018 The Rabbi Arthur Schneier Papers consists of materials created and collected by Rabbi Arthur Schneier over the course of his life as a rabbi and advocate for human rights. The material in the collection dates from 1942 to 2018 with the bulk of the material spanning from the 1970s to the mid 2010s. The content of the collection centers around Schneier's work as an internationally known rabbi and as the president of the Appeal of Conscience Foundation. The bulk of the material present in this collection includes: correspondence, photographs, images, press, clippings, memoranda, and ephemera from various domestic and international events. The collection also contains a small amount of audiovisual material the bulk of which is audio cassette tapes containing recordings of various Appeal of Conscience Foundation events and conferences attended by the rabbi. Materials are primarily in English, with a limited number of materials in Chinese, French, German, Hebrew, Hungarian, Italian, Romanian, Russian, Spanish, and Yiddish.
Conditions Governing Access
Materials are open without restrictions.
Immediate Source of Acquisition
The collection was donated by Rabbi Arthur Schneier in 2017 and 2019. The accession numbers associated with this gift are 2017.035, 2017.067, 2017.075, and 2019.011.
Arrangement
The material in this collection mostly follows the original order of the inventory supplied by Rabbi Arthur Schneier and maintained by Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives. The arrangement of the collection reflects the groupings by subject matter from Rabbi Schneier's inventory. The arrangement is as follows:
Series I. Appeal of Conscience Foundation Material, 1964-2018, undated
Subseries I.A. Annual Seminar on Foreign and Religious Life for the Foreign Service Institute, 1981-2012, undated
Subseries I.B. Annual Awards Dinners and Luncheons, 1969-2018, undated
Subseries I.C. Appeal of Conscience Foundation Delegations to Foreign Countries, 1966-2012, undated

Biographical Note
Rabbi Arthur Schneier (1930- ) was born on March 20, 1930 in Vienna, Austria, and lived under Nazi occupation in Budapest until age 17. Schneier immigrated to the United States in 1947. He graduated with a Bachelor of Arts from Yeshiva University in 1951 and earned a Masters of Arts from New York University in 1953. In 1955, Schneier received his rabbinical ordination from Yeshiva University. Schneier became the Senior Rabbi at Park East Synagogue in 1962. As of 2019, Schneier continues to serve as the Senior Rabbi of Park East Synagogue. Before coming to Park East Synagogue, Schneier served as the rabbi of Congregation B'nai Jacob in Brooklyn, New York. In 1975, Rabbi Arthur Schneier founded the Park East Day School.
Over the years, Rabbi Arthur Schneier has been an active member of many prominent religious and political organizations including: the Council on Foreign Relations, United Nations Development Corporation, United Nations Alliance of Civilizations, and the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum Committee. Schneier founded the Appeal of Conscience Foundation in 1965 and has served as the president of the Foundation since its inception. The Appeal of Conscience Foundation brings together business and religious leaders to promote peace and tolerance internationally and domestically.
Preferred Citation
Identification of item, date; Rabbi Arthur Schneier Papers; TAM 694; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.
Processing Information
At the time of accessioning, July 2017, most of the materials were left in their original file folders and housed primarily in record cartons with spacers as a means to reflect the box inventory written by Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives' Curator, Michael Koncewicz. Further accretions were rehoused in appropriately sized boxes but the original box numbering from the inventory has been maintained. Some boxes donated in the 2019 accrual were not listed on the inventory and were added to the end of the inventory as boxes 192-203.
The collection received minimal rearrangement, rehousing in manuscript boxes, and more granular description during processing from May to October 2019. While the collection had good folder titles, the labels on all of the folders were falling off. Most of the folders in the collection were overfilled and had pieces of dessicated rubber bands stuck to them. The folders were filed within hanging folders and accordion folders. There were several cases of overfilled and underfilled record cartons. During processing, the material in these record cartons were transferred into properly sized boxes and rehoused in scored archival folders. Audiovisual material and physical digital media were housed together as appropriate. Separation sheets were created to sustain the intellectual relationship between paper-based materials and audiovisual materials and physical digital media. Preservation photocopies were created for material printed on thermal fax paper as well as newspaper articles. Hanging folders and accordion folders were removed from the collection. Duplicate material in all formats were deaccessioned from the collection. Original folder titles were used, with descriptive enhancements added as necessary.
Born-digital material was inventoried, labeled, and imaged. Discs were processed using Forensic Toolkit, and video and audio were imaged and uploaded to permanent storage. More than half of the optical discs and floppy disks were deaccessioned due to duplication, damage, or because they contained no files.
New York University Libraries follow professional standards and best practices when imaging, ingesting, and processing born-digital material in order to maintain the integrity and authenticity of the content.
Scope and Contents
The Rabbi Arthur Schneier Papers consists of material collected and created by Rabbi Arthur Schneier dating from 1956 to 2016 pertaining to his work as a rabbi and international advocate for peace, human rights, and religious freedom. The bulk of the collection documents Schneier's work as the president and founder of the Appeal of Conscience Foundation, or ACF, an interfaith coalition of business and religious leaders promoting tolerance and conflict resolution throughout the world. ACF created and co-sponsored protests, seminars, conferences, summits, and awards about creating international peace and tolerance through conflict resolution and the expansion of human and religious rights. Material from these events include: programs, correspondence, schedules, lists of attendees, agendas, press clippings and releases, photographs, images, video recordings, and travel documents. A small number of VHS tapes, microcassette tapes, and audio cassette tapes were recorded of ACF's annual award dinners and luncheons as well as the seminars and conferences co-sponsored and created by ACF. ACF also hosted visiting political and religious leaders of international renown and sent delegations abroad to report to meet with international political and religious leaders. The collection mostly contains paper-based and born-digital material, with a small portion of audio cassette tapes documenting those meetings.
Rabbi Arthur Schneier also attended several domestic and international events as individual advocate for religious tolerance and international peace. A large portion of the collection documents Schneier's constant trips to Israel, Europe, and East Asia to attend international events about religious and human rights. Material from Schneier's trips includes: itineraries, schedules, correspondence, photographs, travel documents and ephemera, and reports. A small number of audio cassette tapes and 16mm films were recorded from various international and domestic events attended by Rabbi Schneier as an advocate for religious rights. Another small part of the collection consists of photographs, images, programs, correspondence, born-digital sound and video recordings that record Rabbi Schneier receiving awards and honorary doctorate degrees for his vocational work as a rabbi and advocate. Finally, this collection contains material that documents Schneier's vocation as a rabbi first as the Rabbi of Congregation B'nai Jacob located in Brooklyn, New York then as the Senior Rabbi of Park East Synagogue in New York, New York.
Conditions Governing Use
This collection is protected by copyright and/or related rights. You are free to use materials in the collection in any way that is permitted by the copyright and related rights legislation that applies to your use. For other uses you need to obtain permission from the rights-holder(s).
Audiovisual Access Policies and Procedures
Audiovisual materials have not been preserved and may not be available to researchers. Materials not yet digitized will need to have access copies made before they can be used. To request an access copy, or if you are unsure if an item has been digitized, please contact special.collections@nyu.edu with the collection name, collection number, and a description of the item(s) requested. A staff member will respond to you with further information.
Appraisal
During accessioning, the curator was able to weed out most of the boxes that contained administrative and/or financial files. However, there were some administrative files embedded within certain boxes, especially the ones that focus on the Annual Award Dinners which were weeded during processing. Additionally, there were several boxes full of unannotated envelopes, invitation and RSVP cards for the Appeal of Conscience Foundation's Annual Awards Dinner. Two copies of the invitations and RSVP cards were retained, the rest of the material was deaccessioned. There were some boxes that contained receipts, tax return forms, tax audit correspondence, reimbursement documents, and a financial investment portfolio for the United States-Japan Foundation that were deaccessioned from the collection. There were several folders of articles, booklets, pamphlets, and reports about international countries which were not created by the Appeal of Conscience Foundation that had little to no research value which were also deaccessioned. In the same vein as the articles, booklets, pamphlets, and reports, the donor also kept folders of speeches by world leaders from various conferences, summits, forum, news conferences that are not annotated which were also discarded. There were two yarmulkes, housed in boxes 108 and 183, that were offered back to the donor and deaccessioned.
After consulting with the digital archivist, six data cartridges were separated from the collection, offered back to the donor, and deaccessioned. These cartridges were labeled as backup files and are currently unable to be imaged by NYU. The digital archivist said they will need to be sent to a vendor and probably do not contain information of high research value. There were a number of optical discs and floppy disks which blank, damaged, or had copyright issues that were deaccessioned from the collection. Please see the deaccessioning checklist in the collection file for a detailed list of optical disc and floppy disk deaccessions.
Two audio cassette tapes were removed from the collection due to copyright issues. Fifteen audio cassette tapes were also removed from the collection, because they were blank. One 16mm film was removed from the collection due to copyright issues.
Electronic Records Policies and Procedures
Advance notice is required for the use of computer records. Original physical digital media is restricted. An access terminal for born-digital materials in the collection is available by appointment for reading room viewing and listening only. Researchers may view an item's original container and/or carrier, but the physical carriers themselves are not available for use because of preservation concerns.
Custodial History
All of the materials in this collection were stored either at the Appeal of Conscience office on 251 West 71st street or at the Park East Synagogue at 163 East 67th street. Material was packed by Rabbi Arthur Schneier and his daughter, Karen Schneier.
Accruals
Additional accruals are expected for this collection.

Scope and Contents
This series contains material collected and created by ACF from 1964 to 2018. This series includes programs, slides, travel documents, itineraries, agendas, schedules, speech transcripts, correspondence, photographs, press, images, audio and video recordings, and ephemera from ACF related events, meetings, and trips. The bulk of the material consists of correspondence created by ACF to inform their donor base about events and activities co-sponsored and created by the Foundation. Included in ACF correspondence are the Foundation's newsletter and correspondence with internationally renowned political and religious dignitaries. Also present in this series are an annual seminar that the Foundation runs for the United States Department of State, and an annual awards dinner and luncheon that serves as the major fundraiser for the Foundation. Since its inception, ACF has hosted many religious and political dignitaries domestically and has also sent many interfaith delegations abroad to promote religious tolerance. This series contains audio recordings, speeches, photographs, press, agendas, schedules, travel documents, and correspondence from all activities related to those types of trips and meetings. There is a small amount of material in this series documenting ACF delegations visiting the Soviet Union to advocate for Soviet Jews throughout the 1970s. There are some brochures, audio recordings, agendas, folders, notes, copies of resolutions, correspondence, and press related material from the international Peace and Tolerance Conferences that ACF co-sponsored and co-ran with the Orthodox Patriarche from 1992-2005.

Scope and Contents
This subseries contains ephemera from the annual seminar that Appeal of Conscience Foundation runs for the State Department's foreign service officers before the officers receive their overseas assignments. The seminar takes place at the Foreign Service Institute, or FSI, and the material in this subseries dates back to 1981. Material in this subseries includes: copies of lectures, photographs, correspondence, information packets, brochures, programs, articles, schedules, images, audio cassette tapes, VHS tapes, video recordings, and filled out questionnaires. There are some born-digital media--images and video in this subseries.

Scope and Contents
This large subseries contains correspondence, programs, speeches, biographical files, press, guest lists, donor lists, photographs, images, audio cassette tapes, VHS tapes, video recordings, and table seating information pertaining to the annual awards dinner, or AAD, and annual awards luncheon, or AAL, created and produced by the Foundation to honor political and business leaders and to fundraise for the Foundation. The initial name of the award given out by the Foundation was the Man of Conscience award which was changed to the Appeal of Conscience Award. An additional award, the World Statesman award, was added to the awards dinner to honor political leaders. The bulk of the material in this subseries are photographs and images of well-known politicians and business leaders such as Vice President Dick Cheney, Brazilian President Fernando Cardoso, Indian President Kocheril Narayanan, German Chancellor Angela Merkel, and Canadian Prime Minister Jean Chretien. Some of the speeches in this subseries are in Spanish, Italian, and German. There are born-digital media--images and video--in this subseries.

Scope and Contents
This subseries contains itineraries, travel documents, correspondence, biographical files of delegates, press, photographs, images, audio cassette tapes, audio and video recordings, and reports from Foundation's delegations visits to foreign countries. Countries visited by the Foundation's delegations include: Argentina, Armenia, Bosnia, Bulgaria, China, Cuba, Czech Republic, Germany, Hungary, Ireland, Israel, Japan, Morocco, Northern Ireland, Panama, Poland, Romania, Spain, Switzerland, Turkey, the Soviet Union, and the Vatican. Some of the material in this subseries are in Bulgarian, Chinese, German, Hebrew, Hungarian, Romanian, Spanish, or Yiddish.

International Political and Religious Leaders Hosted by Appeal of Conscience Foundation3 audiocassettes2.01 Gigabytesin 973 computer files.6.5 Linear Feetin 11.5 manuscript boxes, 1 half manuscript box, .5 small flat box, and 1 media box.1968-2014, undated
Scope and Contents
This subseries contains audio cassette tapes, sound and video recordings, correspondence, images, photographs, newspaper clippings, photographs, schedules, and reports pertaining to the international political and religious leaders that meet with, or were hosted by the Appeal of Conscience Foundation during their visit to the United States. Delegations came from the following countries: Bosnia and Herzegovina, China, Serbia, Yugoslavia, Russia, Romania, and Hungary. Well known religious and political leaders hosted by the Foundation include: Romanian Chief Rabbi Moses Rosen, Rabbi Levin, Ukrainian President Leonid Kravchuk, Russian Orthodox Patriarch Aleksy II, French President Nicolas Sarkozy, and Chinese Ambassador Li Dayou. There are some born-digital media--images, sound and video recordings--in this subseries.

Scope and Contents
This series contains correspondence, itineraries, agendas, schedules, notes, folders, brochures, speeches, lists of participants, travel documents, newspaper clippings, photographs, audio cassette tapes, biographical files of speakers, and programs from the Peace and Tolerance Conferences created and run by ACF. The Peace and Tolerance Conferences were held in 1992, 1995, 1999, 2002, and 2005 in various countries outside of the United States. Two of the conferences in 1994 and 2005 were co-sponsored by the Ecumenical Patriarchate. Some material in this subseries is in Russian, Italian, French, or Hebrew. There are some born-digital media--a word document and pdf files--in this subseries.

Scope and Contents
This subseries contains material in the form of faxes, handwritten letters, and emails between Rabbi Arthur Schneier and ACF's administrative aides, various business and religious dignitaries, and individuals who donated to the Foundation. Of note are some letters circa 1970 between Rabbi Schneier and international rabbinical students interested in studying in the United States and the original newspaper announcement of the founding of ACF in 1965. There is a substantial amount of correspondence about sending Passover supplies to the Cuban Jewish community between the Foundation and members of the Cuban Jewish community. There are also a considerable number of newsletters and press material about the Foundation that were sent out to the Foundation's donors. Some material is in Spanish, Russian, Hebrew, or French. There is a small amount of born-digital media--two files--in this subseries.

Scope and Contents
This large series contains correspondence, programs, itineraries, brochures, packets, press, photographs, audio cassette tapes, vhs tapes, video recordings, images of conferences, summits, forums, dialogues, meetings and other domestic and international events that Rabbi Arthur Schneier attended about creating interreligious peace and expanding human rights. While the bulk of the material in this series comes from Rabbi Schneier's trips to foreign countries, but it also contains events held at PES. Of note in this series are video recordings, images, and correspondence of Pope Benedict XVI's visit to PES, the first papal visit to an American Synagogue, and anniversary events celebrating Rabbi Arthur Schneier's vocational work as the senior rabbi of PES. Included in this series are programs, speech drafts, video recordings, and photographs of Rabbi Arthur Schneier speaking at many Holocaust Remembrance Commemorative Events. Rabbi Arthur Schneier was also the recipient of several domestic and international awards which are documented here in correspondence, photographs, images, video recordings, and programs. Some material in this series is in French, German, Hungarian, Italian, Spanish, or Hebrew. There are born-digital media--video, image, document files--in this series.
Arrangement

II.A. Conferences, Summits, and Forums, 1956-2015, undated
II.B. Commemorative Events, 1976-2016, undated
II.C. Awards and Honorary Degrees, 1976-2011, undatedSubseries II.A. Conferences, Summits, and Forums6 audiocassettes1 videocassettes (vhs)1 film reels44.58 Gigabytesin 4,704 computer files.18 Linear Feetin 1 record carton, 29 manuscript boxes, 3 half manuscript boxes, 2.5 small flat boxes, and 1 media box.1956-2015, undated
Scope and Contents
This large subseries contains programs, agendas, schedules, correspondence, travel documents, speeches, menus, brochures, photographs, images, itineraries, press, video recordings, 16mm film, and VHS tapes from domestic and international conferences, summits, meetings, dinners, luncheons, forums, and other events attended by Rabbi Arthur Schneier. This subseries contains material from events that Rabbi Arthur Schneier attended individually or with his wife Elizabeth Schneier. A couple of these conferences were co-sponsored by the Appeal of Conscience Foundation. Events of note include: the 1960s protests for the rights of Soviet Jews, the 1998 United States religious leaders delegation to China, Rabbi Schneier's multiple trips to Israel, Hungary, and Romania, the 2002 World Economic Forum, and anniversary dinners in honor of Rabbi Arthur Schneier's vocational work as the senior rabbi of PES. Some material in this series is in Chinese, Croatian, French, German, Hebrew, Hungarian, Italian, Romanian, Russian, Spanish, and Yiddish. There are born-digital media--video and images--in this subseries.

Scope and Contents
This subseries contains pamphlets, photographs, images, programs, correspondence, speeches, press clippings, and video recordings of commemorative remembrance events. The bulk of the material from this subseries comes from Holocaust Remembrance events held at PES and the United Nations. Some material in this subseries is in Bosnian, Hungarian, or Hebrew. There are born-digital media--video, image, and document files--in this subseries.

Awards and Honorary Degrees2 audiocassettes7.11 Gigabytesin 1,599 computer files.4.5 Linear Feetin 14 manuscript boxes and .5 media box.1976-2011, undated
Scope and Contents
This small subseries contains correspondence, photographs, emails, images, audio and video recordings, audio cassette tapes, programs, brochures, travel documents, press, and speeches documenting the awards and honorary degrees bestowed upon Rabbi Arthur Schneier. Rabbi Arthur Schneier has received many awards over the course of his including the Presidential Citizens Medal from the United States, Grand Decoration of Honor from Austria, Legion d'honneur from France, the Officer's Cross of the Order of Merit of the Republic of Poland, Order of the Star of Italian Solidarity, and Order of Merit of the Republic of Hungary. Most of Rabbi Arthur Schneier's honorary doctorate degrees were bestowed on him from universities and colleges in the Northeastern region of the United States. Some material is in Hungarian, Spanish, Italian, German, or French. There are born-digital media--emails, audio, image, and video files--in this subseries.

Scope and Contents
This series contains the records of Rabbi Schneier's work as a member, leader, sometimes founder and, at other times, consultant of various organizations dating from 1956 to 2014. Rabbi Schneier helped found and lead American-Romanian Flood Relief, Inc. and the New York Chapter of the Society of Orphanages, Tel Aviv. The material in this series includes article of incorporation, bookets, photographs, board meeting minutes, correspondence, and press clippings. Some of the material is in Romanian or Hebrew. There are born-digital media--document and video files--in this series.

Rabbi of Congregation B'nai Jacob and Park East Synagogue Records2 audiocassettes6 film reels8.45 Gigabytesin 1,975 computer files.25 Linear Feetin 1 record carton, 49 manuscript boxes, 5 half manuscript boxes, 1 small flat box, 2 oversize flat boxes, and 1 media box.1942-2016, undated1965-2016
Scope and Contents
This series contains material created over the course of Rabbi Arthur Schneier's work as a rabbi at Congregation B'nai Jacob and Park East Synagogue. The bulk of the material in this series are photographs of Rabbi Arthur Schneier in his vocation as a rabbi, correspondence between Rabbi Arthur Schneier and his congregants, issues of The Chronicle PES' newsletter, and press about Rabbi Arthur Schneier's work as a rabbi. Material in this series in includes audio cassette tapes, 16mm and 8mm films, correspondence, photographs, notes, menus, invitations, programs, schedules, speeches, publications, press, sermons, booklets, images, and video recordings. Of note are the photographs of Rabbi Arthur Schneier with Robert Kennedy, Mayor Wagner, and Judge Benjamin Glassman from 1965 and 16mm films of Schneier speaking at a Synagogue in Moscow, Soviet Union circa 1975, press and programs documenting Rabbi Schneier's move from Congregation B'nai Jacob to PES, and Rabbi Arthur Schneier's correspondence about the plight of Soviet Jews. There are born-digital media--image files--in this series.
